thread.title: Seven things we've learned in the EU referendum aftermath
thread.title_full: Seven things we've learned in the EU referendum aftermath

author: Tom Eden
title: Seven things we've learned in the EU referendum aftermath
text:
Seven things we've learned in the EU referendum aftermath 19:44, 24 Jun 2016 From David Cameron and Jeremy Corbyn's futures, to what's next for Brexit, here's a run down from a remarkable day in British politics Shares Get daily news by email UKIP Leader Nigel Farage at the Leave EU party in London 
Britain is set to leave the EU after one of the highest voter turn outs in years. 
Here is a round up of some of the key things we’ve learned following the Leave vote and the consequences on Friday. 
Voters in Gateshead, North Tyneside, South Tyneside, Sunderland and County Durham all decided to back the Brexit campaign. 
In Newcastle, there was a narrow win - by 1,800 votes - for the region to remain in the EU. 
Nationwide it became clear at around 4.45am on Friday as counting continued that the Leave campaign had won, with around 52% of the national vote. BBC analysts calculated it was impossible for the remain campaign to win, based on the votes counted so far. 
The nation’s decision was a victory for the leave campaign backed by Boris Johnson, the senior Conservative seen as the most likely candidate to succeed David Cameron as Tory leader. 
The official result was announced at 6am. 
The North East overwhelmingly voted to leave the EU 
Voters went to the polls on Thursday and by the time most people had woken up, the future of our nation was clear — Britain wanted to leave the EU. 
However, it was much earlier that the North East sent out a signal that it was going to be a good night for the Leave campaign. 
As polls closed, the Remain camp seem buoyed by the high turnout and the last few polls suggesting they were on course for the victory. Mary Turner/PA Wire Boris Johnson holds a press conference at Brexit HQ in Westminster, London 
But the shockwaves from the region’s first declared results reached American actress Lindsay Lohan, who then sent social media into overdrive over her Sunderland tweets. 
Nationally, they claimed victory by 52% to Remain’s 48%, with a turnout of 72%, but that margin was much higher in the North East, with 58% of voters crossing the ‘leave’ box on the ballot paper. 
The result cost David Cameron his job 
If you cast your mind back to when David Cameron was the new, fresh-faced leader of the Conservatives, he told the party they had alienated voters by “banging on” about Europe. 
The Tory party has long been divided over the issue of Europe, and Cameron is not the first scalp it has claimed. 
Under the Farage-led UKIP surge before the last election, the spectre of Europe reared its head once more. To stave off the perceived threat of UKIP and to appease the eurosceptic wing of his party, Cameron bowed to demands for a referendum on our EU membership. Christopher Furlong/Getty Images A European Union flag, with a hole cut in the middle, flies at half-mast outside a home in Knutsford Cheshire after today's historic referendum on June 24, 2016 in Knutsford, United Kingdom 
After negotiation concessions from other European countries — abeit minor ones, according to critics — Cameron put his reputation and, ultimately, his job on the line. 
The morning after the result, the PM, flanked by his wife Samantha, came out of Number 10 Downing Street where he announced he was to step down by October. 
The visibly emotional prime minister said: “I do not think it would be right for me to try to be the captain that steers our country to its next destination. 
“This is not a decision I’ve taken lightly but I do believe it’s in the national interest to have a period of stability and then the new leadership required. 
“There is no need for a precise timetable today but in my view we should aim to have a new prime minister in place by the start of the Conservative Party conference in October. 
“Delivering stability will be important and I will continue in post as Prime Minister with my Cabinet for the next three months.” 
The battle to be the next PM has begun 
With Cameron setting out the timetable for selecting the next prime minister, we now have three months of Tory leadership battles to look forward to. 
Boris Johnson is the favourite to succeed his Old Etonian school chum at No 10. Mr Johnson previously insisted he had less chance of taking the top job than being “reincarnated as an olive” but his protestations have done little to disguise his leadership ambitions. After leading the Brexiteers to victory his stock among the widely Eurosceptic Conservatives grassroots will be higher than ever. 
Fellow Vote Leave campaigner Michael Gove has seen his public profile increase even more over the last few weeks as one of the leading figures in the successful campaign, which will do him no harm among Tory party members. 
Two of the most likely remain-backing candidates to challenge for the top role are home secretary Theresa May and the PM’s close political ally George Osborne, who have both been very quiet in the wake of the leave vote. 
However, at this stage nobody knows, as the Labour party would happily testify with Jeremy Corbyn beating 100-1 odds to claim their own leadership battle last year. John Linton/PA Wire Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn 
And Jeremy Corbyn’s future is also under threat 
Dame Margaret Hodge has submitted a motion - seconded by backbencher Ann Coffey - to the Parliamentary Labour Party calling for a motion of no confidence in Jeremy Corbyn. 
She told Sky News: “The European referendum was a test of leadership and I think Jeremy failed that test,” 
“He came out too slowly, he was very half-hearted about his attempts to campaign and Labour voters simply didn’t get the message.” 
Dame Margaret said any vote in the Parliamentary Labour Party would be by secret ballot so rebels would not have to declare their opposition publicly: 
“I hope, in the context of a secret ballot, that there will be overwhelming support for this motion I am putting and Jeremy will do the decent thing and resign.” 
A spokesman for Mr Corbyn condemned the motion as a “self-indulgent act”, although he acknowledged it had been discussed at a post-referendum meeting of the shadow cabinet. 
“It is a time when our party should be uniting to deal with the real issues that face Britain and the real issues that face the people of Britain, and so to create divisions in the party is a bit of a self-indulgent act,” the spokesman said. 
The motion comes amid mounting criticism of Mr Corbyn’s failure to galvanise traditional Labour voters in support of Remain - with northern strongholds voting for Leave. 
Despite the victory for leave, there won’t be a Brexit any time soon... Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
David Cameron has said there will be no rush to begin the formal withdrawal, insisting no decision to leave would be taken for at least the three months he remains PM. 
Boris Johnson, seen as frontrunner in the race to replace Mr Cameron, also said there was “no need for haste” in taking a decision. 
The former Mayor of London has said there will be no rush to leave the EU and claimed there would be no changes in the short term. 
The leader of the Vote Leave campaign attempted to ease fears about Brexit, insisting that there was no need to invoke Article 50 yet - the procedure which triggers a fixed two-year countdown to leaving the EU. 
He said. “As the Prime Minister has just said, nothing will change over the short term except that work will have to begin on how to give effect to the will of the people and to extricate this country from the supranational system.” 
...which will annoy the EU even more 
The UK should implement Brexit “as soon as possible, however painful that process may be”, senior EU representatives have said, warning that “any delay would unnecessarily prolong uncertainty”. 
But, in a joint statement, European Council president Donald Tusk, European Parliament president Martin Schulz, Dutch prime minister Mark Rutte, holder of the rotating presidency of the Council of the EU, and European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker made clear they expected swift progress. Video loading Click to play Tap to play The Live Event you are trying to watch is either unavailable or has not started Please refresh this page in your browser to reload this live event video 
In a joint statement, they said: “In a free and democratic process, the British people have expressed their wish to leave the European Union. We regret this decision but respect it. 
“We now expect the United Kingdom Government to give effect to this decision of the British people as soon as possible, however painful that process may be. 
“Any delay would unnecessarily prolong uncertainty. We have rules to deal with this in an orderly way.” 
This may not be the end of referendums 
SNP leader Nicola Sturgeon also gave a speech, in which she said the Scottish government are looking at having another independence referendum after the UK voted to leave the EU, despite Scotland voting in favour to remain. 
The Scottish Government will therefore draw up legislation to allow a second independence referendum to be held, the first minister confirmed. 
While the UK as a whole voted to leave the European Union, Scots overwhelmingly opted to remain, with Ms Sturgeon declaring the result meant there had been a “significant and material change in the circumstances in which Scotland voted against independence” in 2014. 
She said: 
“As things stand, Scotland faces the prospect of being taken out of the EU against our will. I regard that as democratically unacceptable.” More on the EU Referendum
